The College Crest
 }} The '''Eastern Nazarene College''' (or '''ENC''') is a [[Private university#United States|private]], [[Mixed-sex education|coeducational]] [[Liberal arts colleges in the United States|college of the liberal arts and sciences]] in [[Quincy, Massachusetts]] near [[Boston]], in the [[New England]] region of the [[United States]]. Known for its strong [[Religion|religious]] affiliation, distinctive [[liberal arts]] [[core curriculum]], and excellence in [[science and religion]] education. Its academic programs are primarily [[undergraduate]], with some [[professional]] [[Postgraduate|graduate]] education offered. The [[Residence hall|residential]] [[campus]], in [[Wollaston Park]] near [[Quincy Bay]], is served by the [[Wollaston (MBTA station)|Wollaston MBTA station]], and was once the summer home of [[Boston]] [[mayor]] [[Josiah Quincy, Jr.]] Established as a [[Holiness Movement|holiness]] college in [[Saratoga Springs, New York]] in 1900, it was relocated to [[Massachusetts]] in 1919. ==History== ===New York=== [[Image:Lapham.jpg|thumb|left|Pentecostal Collegiate Institute at the Rhode Island campus, c. 1905]] On September 25, 1900, several [[come-outer]] [[Methodist Episcopal Church|Methodist]] [[clergy]] and [[laity|laymen]] affiliated with the 19th century [[Holiness movement]] opened a [[co-educational]] [[collegiate institute]] at the Garden View House in [[Saratoga Springs, New York]].{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 17 }} In a time when ''pentecostal'' did not hold the same meaning as it does [[Pentecostalism|today]], but rather served as a synonym for ''[[Sacred#Holiness_in_Christianity|holiness]]'',{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Birth of a Church | work = | publisher = Church of the Nazarene | date = | url = http://www.usamission.org/Portals/1/Documents/Birth%20of%20a%20Church2%20(1).pdf | format = | doi = | accessdate = July 24, 2009}}{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = History of the Church of the Nazarene | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.nazarene.org/ministries/administration/archives/history/turn/display.aspx | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} it was named the [[Pentecostal Collegiate Institute]] (PCI) and established for the purpose of providing [[liberal education]] and [[Christian ministry|ministry]] training in a [[College preparatory|preparatory]] [[academy]], four-year [[College#United_States|college]], and [[Theology|theological]] [[seminary]].{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | pages = 20â21 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }} PCI operated under the auspices of the Association of Pentecostal Churches of America (APCA), a [[Congregationalist polity|loose association]] of [[Wesleyanism|Wesleyan]]-holiness churches{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | pages = 27 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }} from eastern [[Canada]] down to the [[Middle Atlantic]], and its own [[board of education]],{{cite journal | first = Stan | last = Ingersol | author = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Why These Schools? Historical Perspectives on Nazarene Higher Education | version = | publisher = | date = | url = http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/Why%20These%20Schools%20%20Historical%20Perspectives%20on%20Nazarene%20Higher%20Education.pdf | format = [[PDF]] | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} with [[Lyman C. Pettit]] as its first president. PCI was also accredited by the [[New York State Education Department]]'s [[Board of Regents]] of the [[University of the State of New York]]{{cite book | last = Smith | first = Timothy L. | authorlink = Timothy L. Smith | coauthors = | title = Called Unto Holiness | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1962 | location = Kansas City | url = http://wesley.nnu.edu/wesleyctr/books/2501-2600/HDM2593.PDF | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = }} and was given state funding because a public school did not exist there at the time. In 1901, the institute changed locations in Saratoga Springs, from the Garden View House to the former Kenmore Hotel.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Saratoga Hotel Sold | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = ''[[The New York Times]]'' | date = September 17, 1901 | url = http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9802E2D7163BE733A25754C1A96F9C946097D6CF&oref=slogin | accessdate = 2008-07-10 | format=PDF}} ===Rhode Island=== The initial plans for a [[liberal arts college]] were delayed, however.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | pages = 28â29, 33 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }} There was a falling out between Pettit and the APCA, and the school re-opened on September 16, 1902, in [[North Scituate, Rhode Island]],{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = ''Scituate, Rhode Island'' | publisher = Arcadia Publishing | year = 1998 | location = | url = http://books.google.com/?id=Qyo1ui9T_gMC&printsec=frontcover | doi = | id = | isbn = 0738564192 | page = 127}} without a [[post-secondary]] curriculum.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | pages = 33â36 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }} Having been the originator of the idea for establishing PCI and having already surveyed the Rhode Island location,{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | pages = 32â33}} [[Fred A. Hillery]] had purchased the North Scituate campus on behalf of the association.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 34 }} Originally "built and equipped for $78,000," Hillery bought it for $4,500 and negotiated a mortgage for $3,000. Its [[Greek Revival]] buildings were originally designed for the [[Smithville Seminary]] in 1839 by [[Russell Warren (architect)|Russell Warren]], the leading Greek Revival architect in [[New England]] in the 19th century,{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = Beth L. Savage and Carol D. Shull | title = ''African American Historic Places'' | publisher = John Wiley and Sons | year = 1995 | location = | url = http://books.google.com/?id=wjZIkchWX5AC&printsec=frontcover | doi = | id = | isbn =9780471143451 | page = 422 }} but had been unused since the Lapham Institute closed in 1876. Attendance became multi-denominational after the move, only one-quarter to one-third of the student body being affiliated with the school's supporting denomination during any given academic year.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | pages = 46, 53, 61, 175}} In 1907, the APCA merged with the [[Church of the Nazarene]],{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 52 }} and PCI became one of the first three schools chosen to be officially affiliated with the Nazarenes in 1908.{{cite book | last = Raser | first = Harold E. | authorlink = | coauthors = Thomas C. Hunt, James C. Carper, eds. | title = Religious Higher Education in the United States | publisher = Taylor & Francis | year = 1996 | location = | url = http://books.google.com/?id=lxr_PID7o2IC&printsec=frontcover&q | doi = | id = | isbn = 0815316364 | page = 547 }} In 1917, it was decided to re-establish the liberal arts college,{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | pages = 125â126}} and on June 14, 1918, the Eastern Nazarene College was chartered with [[academic degree|degree]]-granting authority in the state of [[Rhode Island]],{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 130}}{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 137}} while [[secondary education]] would remain as the Eastern Nazarene Academy.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = The Spirit Makes the Difference: The History of Eastern Nazarene College, Part II, 1950-2000 | publisher = ENC Press | year = 2000 | location = Quincy, Massachusetts | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 57}} Choosing a new name, however, would be difficult: the school was now a liberal arts college and a Nazarene institution. Candidates included: "Northeastern Nazarene College", "[[Bresee]] Memorial College", "Nazarene College of the [[Northeastern United States|Northeast]]", and "Nazarene College and Bresee Theological Institute". [[General Superintendent (Church of the Nazarene)|General Superintendent]] [[John W. Goodwin]] can be credited with the chosen name, as he wrote to [[Hiram F. Reynolds]], also a general superintendent and a long-time supporter of the school: "I know you will do your best for our New England College. I should be glad if they would change the name to the Eastern Nazarene College, or something like that. It would seem we must have a school there, although it moves along hard and slow." ===Massachusetts=== In 1919, the college moved to its current location in the [[Wollaston (Quincy, Massachusetts)|Wollaston Park]] area of [[Quincy, Massachusetts]]. The founders wanted the new college to be located near either [[Harvard]] or [[Yale]], for its graduates to attend [[graduate school]] at one or the other; Quincy won out over [[New Haven, Connecticut]] because the educational standards were known to be higher in [[Massachusetts]]{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | pages = 146â147 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }} and because president-elect [[Fred J. Shields]] would only accept the position if the college were to be located near Boston.{{cite book | last = Munro | first = Bertha | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The Years Teach, an Autobiography: Remembrances to Bless | publisher = Beacon Hill Press | year = 1970 | location = Kansas City | pages = | url = http://wesley.nnu.edu/wesleyctr/books/3401-3500/HDM3426.pdf | doi = | id = | isbn = }} At the time of its purchase, the {{convert|12|acre|m2|sing=on}} property consisted of the [[Josiah Quincy Mansion]] (1848), built by [[Josiah Quincy, Jr.]]{{cite book | last = Pepe | first = William J. | authorlink = | coauthors = Elaine A. Pepe | title = Postcard History Series: Quincy | publisher = Arcadia Publishing | year = 2008 | location = | pages = 72 | url = http://books.google.com/?id=NBQrnXx79-UC&printsec=frontcover#PPA72,M1 | doi = | id = | isbn =9780738555393 }} where Angell Hall now stands, a classroom building called the Manchester (1896), the stables (1848) on the site where Memorial Hall was built in 1948, and the Canterbury (1901), which is now Canterbury Hall. From the captain's walk of the mansion, [[Wollaston Bay]] was clearly visible down to the "ships entering and leaving the port of Boston."{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 147}} The former Rhode Island campus was purchased in 1920 by William S. Holland, who moved his [[Watchman Institute]] there in 1923. {| class=wikitable align="right" |+Presidents |- | || [[J. E. L. Moore]] || 1918â1919 |- |1. || [[Fred J. Shields|Frederick James Shields]] || 1919â1923 |- |2. || [[Floyd William Nease]] || 1923â1930 |- |3. || [[Robert Wayne Gardner]] || 1930â1936 |- |4. || [[Gideon Brooks Williamson]] || 1936â1944 |- |5. || [[Samuel Young (General Superintendent)|Samuel Young]] || 1944â1948 |- |6. || [[Edward Stebbins Mann]] || 1948â1970 |- |7. || A. Leslie Parrott, Jr. || 1970â1975 |- |8. || Donald Irwin || 1975â1980 |- |9. || [[Stephen Wesley Nease]] || 1980â1989 |- |10. || [[Cecil Roland Paul]] || 1989â1992 |- |11. || [[Kent R. Hill]] || 1992â2001 |- | || Albert L. Truesdale, Jr. || 2001â2002 |- |12. || J. David McClung || 2002â2005 |- |13. || Corlis A. McGee || 2005- |} The trustees of the college were incorporated by the state in 1920,{{cite book | last = Hood | first = William Ross | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = State Laws Relating to Education Enacted in 1920 and 1921 | publisher = Department of the Interior: Bureau of Education | year = 1922 | location = District of Columbia | url = http://books.google.com/?id=snQaAAAAYAAJ | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 224 }} by which time its [[liberal arts]] identity had been "quite firmly established," but it took another decade to gain [[bachelor of arts]] degree-granting power from the commonwealth.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 163 }} Before 1930, an arrangement was made with [[Northwest Nazarene College]] for students to receive degrees from that institution instead. President [[Floyd W. Nease]] appealed directly to the [[General Court of Massachusetts]], and defended his petition before the Joint Committee on Education and the House and Senate on January 28, 1930, calling on financial records, campus improvement plans, and prominent community leaders; the bill passed in both houses and was signed by Governor [[Frank G. Allen]] on March 12, 1930.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | pages = 194â195 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }} The news reached the college the following afternoon.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Gov. Allen Signs Nazarene College Degree Grant Bill | work = [[The Patriot Ledger]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = March 14, 1930 | url = | accessdate = July 24, 2009}} The next year under President [[R. Wayne Gardner]], the [[trustee]]s made a statement reaffirming that the college would remain "distinctly [[interdenominational]] and cosmopolitan in service."{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 263 }} The college seal, designed by [[alumnus]] Harold G. Gardner and symbolically incorporating the college [[motto]], ''[[Via, Veritas, Vita]]'', was adopted by the trustees on the recommendation of the president and the student body in 1932,In large part from [[Jesus]]' words, "I am the way and the truth and the life...." from {{bibleverse||John|14:6|131}}, as well as the statement from [[natural science]] professor Jesse B. Mowry (with [[master's degree]] from [[Brown University]] and a [[doctor of science]] degree from [[Norwich University]]) that, "Yea, the Truth points the Way and the Life, and these three determine man's destiny!" {{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | pages = 38, 220}} along with a college banner to display the [[emblem]]s of ''[[Verbum]]'', ''[[Lux]]'', ''[[Spiritus]]'', ''[[Crux]]''. The college had been chartered in 1918 with a [[music school|school of music]], President Gardner secured certification for the college as a teacher-training institution with the [[Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education|Massachusetts Department of Education]] in 1933,{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | pages = 248, 401}} and the college would institute a [[Postgraduate education|graduate]] program in [[theology]] starting in 1938,{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 333}} thus becoming one of only two Nazarene schools to offer anything beyond a [[bachelor of arts]] before 1945. [[Evolutionary biology]] was taught in the classroom at least as early as 1937,{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 318}} and on May 8, 1941, Governor [[Leverett Saltonstall]] approved Eastern Nazarene to grant [[bachelor of science]] degrees. ENC also had a cooperative degree program in engineering with [[Northeastern University]] by 1943.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 330}} [[Image:gatesealENC.jpg|thumb|left|College seal on the main campus gate, a gift of the class of 1938]] Under President [[Gideon B. Williamson]] on December 3, 1943, the Eastern Nazarene College gained [[Educational accreditation|accreditation]] from the [[New England Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools]],{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene CollegeâThe First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 293}} and became the second Nazarene college to ever gain institutional accreditation.{{cite book | last = Purkiser | first = Westlake Taylor | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Called Unto Holiness, Vol. 2 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1983 | location = Kansas City | url = http://wesley.nnu.edu/wesleyctr/books/2601-2700/HDM2623.PDF | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = }} The first was the [[Northwest Nazarene College]] in [[Idaho]], which was accredited as a four-year school in 1937, while ENC alumnus [[Russell V. DeLong]] was president there. ENC was also admitted to the [[Association of American Colleges]] in 1944, and an affiliation with [[Quincy City Hospital]] for nurses' training began in that same year. Eastern Nazarene was soon dubbed "Our Quincy's College" by the Quincy ''[[Patriot Ledger]]''{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Our Quincy's College | work = | pages = 1, 4 | language = | publisher = ''[[The Patriot Ledger]]'' | date = October 5, 1948 | url = | accessdate = }} and has since maintained good [[town and gown]] relations with the city.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Editorial: Quincy home to more collegians | work = [[Patriot Ledger]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = August 23, 1996 | url = | accessdate = July 24, 2009}} The Eastern Nazarene Academy would close after 1955, and starting in 1956, professors [[Timothy L. Smith]] and [[Charles W. Akers]] began to establish a [[community college]] for the city of Quincy.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = History Department | work = | publisher = Eastern Nazarene College | date = | url = http://www.enc.edu/history/dept_hist.html | doi = | accessdate = August 4, 2009}} In 1964, the graduate course in theology was discontinued and replaced with a [[master's degree]] program in religion.{{cite book | last = Balmer | first = Randall Herbert | authorlink = Randall Herbert Balmer | coauthors = | title = ''Encyclopedia of Evangelicalism'' | publisher = Baylor University Press | year = 2004 | location = | url = http://books.google.com/?id=Vjwly0QyeU4C&pg=PA532&lpg=PA532&dq=pentecostal+collegiate+institute | doi = | id = | isbn =9781932792041 | page = 224 }} The college archives were created in 1963 and the first history of the college, spanning from 1900 to 1950, was published by [[James R. Cameron]] in 1968.{{cite news | last = Davis | first = Joy | coauthors = | title = Second volume added to Eastern Nazarene history | work = [[The Patriot Ledger]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = December 5, 2000 | url = | accessdate = July 24, 2009}} Under President Irwin in 1977, there arose plans to relocate the college to a {{convert|125|acre|m2|sing=on}} parcel of land in [[Newtown Square, Pennsylvania]], by purchasing the faltering Charles E. Ellis School for Girls.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene College Leaving Massachusetts for Pennsylvania | work = | pages = 5 | language = | publisher = ''[[The New York Times]]'' | date = March 20, 1977 | url = | accessdate = 2009-04-15}} The proposed move was very unpopular among students and members of the Quincy community, even Governor [[Michael Dukakis]] urged to administration to reconsider, but the relocation never took place because the college was outbid for the land by a corporation that wanted to establish an [[industrial park]] there.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = The Spirit Makes the Difference: The History of Eastern Nazarene College, Part II, 1950-2000 | publisher = ENC Press | year = 2000 | location = Quincy, Massachusetts | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 283 }}{{cite web | last = Ferguson | first = Gailynne M. | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = History of the Ellis School | work = | publisher = EllisAlum.org | date = March 30, 1999 | url = http://www.ellisalum.org/Ellis/History.htm | doi = | accessdate = July 24, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In 1981, [[graduate degree]] offerings were expanded, and an accelerated program for working adults was started in 1990.{{cite web | last = Salter | first = Sue | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =From the Chair | work = News Vol. 7 No. 2 | publisher = Consortium for the Advancement of Adult Higher Education | date = Summer 1997 | url = http://www.caahe.org/publications/news_1997_06.pdf | format = PDF | doi = | accessdate = 2009-05-29}} In 1991, a report issued by the Association of Independent Colleges and Universities in Massachusetts (AICUM){{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Association of Independent Colleges and Universities in Massachusetts (AICUM) | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.masscolleges.org/ | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-05-29}} determined that the college contributed nearly $10 million to the local economy and brought in an estimated $7 million from outside the state.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = ENC Boosts Local Economy By Nearly $10 Million | work = | pages = 33 | language = | publisher = ''The [[Quincy Sun]]'' | date = October 31, 1991 | url = | accessdate = }} In 1992, President [[Kent R. Hill|Kent Hill]] approved a policy to only hire [[Christian]] professors at the college, a move that initially stirred some controversy in the media but was meant for the hiring of new faculty rather than the dismissal of then-current faculty, and was deemed by the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) to be reasonable according to [[civil rights]] laws.{{cite news | last = Coakley | first = Tom | coauthors = | title = Faculty shift ahead at Christian college | work = [[Boston Globe]] | pages = | language = | publisher = http://www.proquest.com/ | date = April 27, 1993 | url = | accessdate = July 23, 2009}} A second history of the college, spanning from 1950 to 2000, was started in 1993. [[Image:Babcockarboretumtree.jpg|thumb|right|The college campus is also home to the Babcock Arboretum.]] The {{convert|21|acre|m2|sing=on}} main campus{{cite map |publisher = |title = Campus map |url Massachusetts]]. The Wollaston Park campus is roughly {{convert|1.5|mi|km}} southeast from the [[Boston]] [[Neponset River|city line]] and {{convert|6|mi|km}} south of [[Government Center, Boston|downtown Boston]],{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene College: About | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.enc.edu/about/index.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2009-05-19}} just over {{convert|1|mi|km}} north of [[Quincy Center]], {{convert|0.5|mi|km}} northeast of the [[Wollaston (MBTA station)|Wollaston T station]],{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Wollaston MBTA Station (with Google map) | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.mbta.com/schedules_and_maps/subway/lines/stations/?stopId=15412 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} and {{convert|0.25|mi|km}} southwest from [[Wollaston Beach]]. ENC purchased the Wollaston Park property, then a {{convert|12|acre|m2|sing=on}} parcel, from the former Quincy Mansion School for Girls for $50,000 in 1919, and has added to it over the years. The [[Mount Wollaston]] land belonging to the [[Quincy family]] had been broken up into prestigious building lots and named Wollaston Park during in the late 19th century, to become one of Boston's first [[commuter]] neighborhoods,Information provided by the Eastern Nazarene College, [http://books.google.com/books?id=IdoCHAAACAAJ History of the Babcock Arboretum, published in 2003, written by Gerry Wood], founder. Found in the Nease Library, Reference Section. and the area remains primarily [[Residential area|residential]]. The campus is also a registered [[arboretum]], named the Babcock Arboretum after Vernor J. Babcock and dedicated in 1993. The ''[[alma mater]]'', set to the tune of "[[Annie Lisle]]" with lyrics written by former president Edward S. Mann, not only refers to Quincy Bay but also the existence of the [[elm]] trees for which Elm Avenue was named,{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Alumni Relations at Eastern Nazarene College | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.enc.edu/IA/alumni_relations.php | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-12-30}} all of which died with the onset of [[Dutch elm disease]] in the early to mid-20th century. The college has historically maintained good [[town and gown]] relations with the Quincy community, and the campus has been home to the Anglican Parish of Saint George, established by the Anglican Mission in America, since 2009.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = New Anglican Church | work = [[The Patriot Ledger]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = February 28, 2009 | url = | accessdate = July 24, 2009}} The [[Quincy Mansion]] (1848) purchased by the college in 1919 was demolished in 1969. Its [[chandelier]]s were sold for food during the [[Great Depression]]. It was once part of the Quincy family homestead along with the [[Dorothy Quincy House]] and the [[Josiah Quincy House]], on a {{convert|200|acre|km2|sing=on}} parcel of land known as the "Lower Farm". The mansion itself was situated on the land where Angell Hall now stands, and was the summer home of [[Josiah Quincy, Jr.]], then mayor of Boston. It was three stories and white, in [[Georgian architecture]], with marble fireplaces in most of the rooms and large [[French window]]s on the first floor that "opened upon either little balconies or broad [[piazza]]s." Elm Avenue had been the avenue, or driveway, for the two mansions on the property. The first of the two, the Josiah Quincy House (1770), still stands on Muirhead Street. [[Image:GardnerHallENC.JPG|thumb|right|Gardner Hall (1930), the main college administration building]] Both Gardner Hall (1930), originally named the Fowler Memorial Administration Building after [[Charles J. Fowler]], and the original Floyd W. Nease Library (1953), now the Bower-Grimshaw Center for Institutional Advancement, were designed by Wesley Angell. Gardner Hall was designed in the [[Classical architecture|Classical]] or [[Colonial Revival architecture|Colonial Revival]] mode. Gardner is brick, three stories on a high granite basement, and capped by a [[parapet]] [[balustrade]]d in the center. Corners are articulated with brick [[quoin (architecture)|quoins]]. The fenestration is symmetric with double sash windows at regular intervals, trimmed in white, topped with flared brick [[lintel]]s and a white [[keystone (architecture)|keystone]]. It also features a two-story balustraded [[Doric order|Doric]] [[portico]] of fluted cast stone [[column]]s. The portico is the backdrop for [[commencement speech|commencement]] ceremonies. The main entrance, at the end of wide stairs, is pilastered and topped with a bracketed entablature, which frames an arched glass opening. The side elevations have projecting stair towers, which indicate the site of a central hall running the length of the building. Originally rectangular in form, the 1953 addition of the then-Nease Library in the rear bestowed upon it a T-configuration.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Historical and architectural significance of the campus of Eastern Nazarene College | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://thomascranelibrary.org/htm/503.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} [[File:Memorial Hall, Eastern Nazarene College(2).jpg|thumb|left|Memorial Hall (1948), for those who served and died in World War II]] Memorial Hall (1948) holds the distinction of the only building on campus, other than the pre-existing Canterbury Hall (1901), not to be named for any one individual. Rather, it was built as a memorial to those who had served in the [[Second World War]]. Over two hundred alumni had served, and six students had given their lives.{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | coauthors = | title = The Spirit Makes the Difference: The History of Eastern Nazarene College, Part II, 1950-2000 | publisher = ENC Press | year = 2000 | location = Quincy, Massachusetts | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 11 }} ===Old Colony and other locations=== The {{convert|6|acre|m2|sing=on}} Old Colony Campus (OCC), named for its location on Old Colony Avenue in Quincy, has two buildings. The 180 building is the Adams Executive Center, which houses the business department in the Cecil R. Paul Center for Business, established in 1999. The building at 162 Old Colony houses the college archives and offices for the history department as part of the James R. Cameron Center for History, Law, and Government, established in 2005, as well as separate offices for mathematics, and physics and engineering departments, and the Campus Kinder Haus (CKH), an early childhood education center.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Photo tour: Campus Kinder Haus | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www1.enc.edu/subpage.aspx?id=1009 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-01-03}} CKH was founded in 1979 and moved to the Old Colony Campus in 2000.{{cite news | last = Davis | first = Joy | coauthors = | title = Kinder Haus finally at home | work = [[The Patriot Ledger]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 26, 2000 | url = | accessdate = July 24, 2009}} The college also owns adjacent undeveloped land between Old Colony and Hancock Street in Quincy, at the Southern Artery,{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Rezoning of parcel debated; it is an expression of the church."{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Manual of the History, Doctrine, Government, and Ritual of the Church of the Nazarene | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 2005 | location = Kansas City | url = http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/Manual2005_09.pdf | doi = | id = | isbn = | page = 170}} Originally founded under the auspices of the [[Association of Pentecostal Churches of America]], ENC was one of the first three schools officially chosen to be [[Church of the Nazarene#Higher education|Nazarene institution]] in 1915, making it the oldest continuously operating educational institution affiliated with the Nazarenes. The president and trustees of the college determined in 1931, one year after gaining its charter to grant degrees in Massachusetts, that it is part of the college's mission to be "distinctly [[interdenominational]] and cosmopolitan in service." The school currently has three college divisions: the Traditional Undergraduate Division, the Adult Studies Division (often called the Leadership Education for Adults Division, or LEAD), and the Graduate Division.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene College 2008-2009 Undergraduate Catalog | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.enc.edu/downloads/undergraduate_catalogs/undergraduate_catalog_08-09.pdf | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-03-08}} There were 1,075 students enrolled at the college in 2007, 927 of whom were [[undergraduate]] and 148 of whom were [[graduate student]]s.{{cite web|url=http://nces.ed.gov/globallocator/|title=Search for Schools, Colleges, and Libraries|publisher=U.S. Department of Education National Center for Education Statistics|accessdate=2009-04-14}} Admission is selective{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene College | work = Carnegie Classification | publisher = Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching | date = | url = http://www.carnegiefoundation.org/classifications/sub.asp?key=748&subkey=14645&start=783 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-05-19}} on a [[Rolling admission|rolling deadline]] and the 2007 acceptance rate for students who applied to the college was 61.7 percent.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene College | work = Guide to Best Colleges | publisher = U.S. News and World Report | date = | url = http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/college/items/2145 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2009-05-19}} ===Traditional Undergraduate Division=== Most degree offerings at Eastern Nazarene are [[Bachelor's|baccalaureate]] degrees. In the Traditional Undergraduate Division, the college offers [[Associate's degree|associate's]] and [[Bachelor's degree|bachelor's]] ([[bachelor of arts]] and [[bachelor of science]]) [[liberal arts]] degrees in 50 [[Academic major|major]]s, with 57 [[Academic minor|minor]]s and 6 pre-professional programs for a combined total of 80 programs of study, including [[dual degree]] programs with [[Northeastern University]] and the [[Massachusetts College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences]] leading to the [[doctor of pharmacy]]. In addition to co-operative programs and internship opportunities around Boston, Eastern Nazarene provides a number of intercollegiate and off-campus programs at 56 [[Church of the Nazarene|Nazarene]] institutions of [[higher education]] around the world. Students may also participate in the "Best Semester"{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Best Semester | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.bestsemester.com/ | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} study abroad program, and ENC offers an additional semester-long program in [[Romania]]. The college uses a "4-1-4 system" for its academic year: there are two full [[Academic term|semesters]] in the [[autumn|Fall]] and Spring, each roughly four months long, and a one-month term in January known as "J Term". Eastern Nazarene emphasizes a blend of faith and other pursuits, from biology{{cite news | last = Lambert | first = Lane | coauthors = | title = Making room for God and evolution; Nazarene prof says they're not mutually exclusive | work = | pages = 1 | language = | publisher = ''[[The Patriot Ledger]]'' | date = March 5, 2008 | url = | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} to business,{{cite news | last = Lambert | first = Lane | coauthors = | title = Speaker preaches faith in the office; Former investment banker says companies should embrace the Lord's work | work = | pages = 10 | language = | publisher = ''[[The Patriot Ledger]]'' | date = November 15, 2006 | url = | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} and has won the [[John Templeton]] award for science-and-religion education.{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Professors honored for science-religion course Eastern Nazarene program explores common ground | work = [[Patriot Ledger]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = August 24, 1996 | url = | accessdate = July 24, 2009}} The undergraduate curriculum at Eastern Nazarene was developed in 1919 by the first dean of the college, Bertha Munro, and originally modeled after the curricula at [[Radcliffe College]] and [[Boston University]]. A revision that introduced the Cultural Perspectives core sequence is very distinctive and comprises a series of [[interdisciplinary]] courses on Western culture that encourages students to ponder the "tensions and possibilities" in the relationships between the Christian faith and societal values. The traditional undergraduate student-to-faculty ratio at Eastern Nazarene is 11:1, and graduates on average have a 94 percent acceptance rate into [[medical school]] as well as a 100 percent acceptance rate into [[law school]].{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Eastern Nazarene College History | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www1.enc.edu/About-ENC/History.aspx | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} ===Graduate Division and LEAD=== [[Image:PaulcenterENC.jpg|thumb|right|College name and shield on the side of the Cecil R. Paul Center for Business at the Old Colony Campus]] In addition to traditional undergraduate education, the college offers [[continuing education]] for working adults through the Leadership Education for Adults Division (LEAD). Accelerated programs have been in place since 1990, and now include bachelor's [[degree completion]] (bachelor of arts and bachelor of science degrees) and [[associate's degree]]s (the [[associate of arts]] degree) as well as certificates in [[paralegal]] studies (CPS) and [[human resource management]] (CHRM).{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Adult and Graduate Programs | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.enc.edu/adult_studies/programs.php | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} The college also maintains 2+2 programs{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = 2+2 BAM Programs | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www1.enc.edu/subpage.aspx?fid=110 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-10}} and [[articulation (education)|articulation]] agreements with [[junior college]]s in the surrounding geographical area, like the agreements with [[Bristol Community College|Bristol]], [[Massasoit Community College|Massasoit]], and [[Roxbury Community College]]s. Most LEAD classes are held at the Old Colony Campus or at one of the four [[satellite campus]]es for reasons of transportation and accessibility, such as parking space, which is limited at the main campus, and access to [[public transportation]] via the [[Wollaston (MBTA Station)|Wollaston T Station]], located on Beale Street where it intersects with Old Colony Avenue. Current [[graduate education|graduate]] offerings from the Graduate Division are primarily [[master's degrees]] ([[master of science]] and [[master of education]]).
